items.title: “Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator....
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. In a time when social injustice is rampant but the fight against it has poured out into the streets, many turn to their artistry in order to express themselves.

However, with so much going on, racial injustice, a global pandemic, police brutality, corruption, it is hard to know where to start. The question for people who want to get involved remains the same — what can I do? However, it is not asked rhetorically. Local artists and the Curious Theatre in Denver found their answer in The Breath Project.”

303 Magazine

Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. In a time when social injustice is rampant but the fight against it has poured out into the streets, many turn to their artistry in ord…

303magazine.com

The Breath Project Gives Artists of Color the Spotlight With 8:46 Minute Performances

Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. In a time when social injustice is rampant but the fight against it has poured out into the streets, many turn to their artistry in ord…Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. items.title: "As experts across the country focus their attention on the...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

"As experts across the country focus their attention on the question, Colorado has ramped up its own effort to create an ethical and logistical framework to distribute the vaccine. The goal is for the process to be rational, fair, transparent and equitable. But, with so many unknowns surrounding the virus, research and vaccine politics still in play, that’s a lot harder than it sounds."

The Colorado Sun

The priority system will depend on a number of factors that doctors and scholars can’t yet assess

coloradosun.com

Months before its arrival, Colorado tries to answer the question: Who should get the coronavirus vaccine first?

The priority system will depend on a number of factors that doctors and scholars can’t yet assessThe priority system will depend on a number of factors that doctors and scholars can’t yet assess

items.title: "As masses of people march for change to law enforcement...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

"As masses of people march for change to law enforcement systems that disproportionately affect people of color, reforms that advocates have demanded for years are resurfacing.

Local and national unrest over the killing of George Floyd while in police custody has propelled long-desired policy changes and seeded new ones in Denver. We’ll follow those changes here."

Denverite

Protests against racism and police brutality are changing policy and names in Denver. We’ll track those changes here.Think of it like editing a Word document except the Word document is society.Protests against racism and police brutality are changing policy and names in Denver. We’ll track those changes here.Think of it like editing a Word document except the Word document is society.See more at DENVERITE.COM

items.title: "COVID-19, in many ways, created an opening for the...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

"COVID-19, in many ways, created an opening for the movement this summer and put Colorado in a unique position to lead on issues of race and policing. Responding to the pandemic, the Colorado General Assembly put itself on hiatus, then pushed back the last legislative date from early May to mid-June—as protests over Floyd and the deaths of others, such as Breonna Taylor in Louisville, Kentucky, and Aurora’s Elijah McClain, were getting recognition in the suburbs surrounding Denver. “If we waited, we’d lose political will to get something done,” says Herod, who’d taken perhaps the biggest legislative role as the author and co-sponsor of what became known as SB20-217, a sweeping police accountability measure that was developed, debated, passed, and signed into law within 16 days. “So, basically, we didn’t wait.”

5280 Magazine

The confluence of COVID-19 and this summer's Black Lives Matter protests brought a new generation of Black leaders to the forefront of Mile High City politics and activism.

5280.com

How Twin Pandemics Transformed Denver's Black Leadership - 5280

The confluence of COVID-19 and this summer's Black Lives Matter protests brought a new generation of Black leaders to the forefront of Mile High City politics and activism.The confluence of COVID-19 and this summer's Black Lives Matter protests brought a new generation of Black leaders to the forefront of Mile High City politics and activism.

items.title: "“Usually I would see 15 or 20 trucks a day leaving the...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

"“Usually I would see 15 or 20 trucks a day leaving the peach-packing facilities, and I haven’t seen one in several days,” Palisade farmer Scott High told The Denver Post last week. “We would sell in excess of a million pounds of peaches (normally), and we’re not selling any this year. So there’s a million pounds less just from our company alone.”"

The Denver Post

“The peaches that I have tasted this year are delicious. There just aren’t that many.”

denverpost.com

In Colorado’s peach country, the season that wasn’t

“The peaches that I have tasted this year are delicious. There just aren’t that many.”“The peaches that I have tasted this year are delicious. There just aren’t that many.”

items.title: "More Colorado households have responded to the U.S. Census...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

"More Colorado households have responded to the U.S. Census Bureau than the national average a little over a month ahead of the deadline, but advocates warn that representation and money is at stake — particularly for hard-to-reach communities — with the agency deciding to call an early end to door-knocking efforts."

The Denver Post

More Colorado households have responded to the U.S. Census Bureau than the national average a little more than a month ahead of the deadline, but advocates warn that representation and money is at …

denverpost.com

Colorado’s census response higher than national rate, but advocates say it’s not enough as early end nears

items.title: “Denver’s skies are bluer now that some rain broke the heat...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Denver’s skies are bluer now that some rain broke the heat and clouds of smoke that hung over the city for weeks. Colorado is still wrestling with wildfires, but firefighters have recently made progress containing a few of them. Local air quality sensors show smoke has abated since readings peaked last week.

If you want a general idea about air quality in Denver, the EPA’s AirNow portal or Colorado’s air quality site will get the job done. They present average “air quality index” numbers, or AQI, measured in the city over a 24-hour period. “

Denverite

Right now, experts recommend using national tools, but the city is working on a Denver-centric app to help keep your lungs happy.

denverite.com

How to keep tabs on Denver air quality and figure out when to maybe stay inside

Right now, experts recommend using national tools, but the city is working on a Denver-centric app to help keep your lungs happy.Right now, experts recommend using national tools, but the city is working on a Denver-centric app to help keep your lungs happy.

items.title: “Petitioners are ready, willing, and able to litigate the...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Petitioners are ready, willing, and able to litigate the issues raised in this
petition in either the state District Court in Denver, or the United States District Court for the District of Colorado, or both,” the lawsuit said.

Polis said Malkin and Neville, in filing the lawsuit, were showing they are “on the side of a deadly virus that has taken the lives of too many friends, parents, and loved ones.”

...

The Colorado Sun

See MoreThe court made the decision less than two days after the legal action was submitted by Colorado House Minority Leader Patrick Neville and Michelle Malkin

coloradosun.com

Colorado Supreme Court declines to hear Republican challenge to Gov. Jared Polis’ mask mandate

items.title: “The police hiring process needs to result in more diverse...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The police hiring process needs to result in more diverse candidates that reflect Aurora’s population. (A department-wide probe, announced in August, is looking into that.) As of July 14, 80 percent of the department’s more than 750 officers are white. People of color make up more than 50 percent of the city’s population.

“If you’re not really looking at how you’re hiring, how you’re disciplining … really (at) some systematic issues, it’s just going to be a revolving door,” Johnston said.”

Denverite

Banning no-knock warrants and ketamine. Introducing a police auditor. Revamping the police department’s disciplinary process.

denverite.com

What changes are in store for Aurora police? Local lawmakers have some ideas.

Banning no-knock warrants and ketamine. Introducing a police auditor. Revamping the police department’s disciplinary process.Banning no-knock warrants and ketamine. Introducing a police auditor. Revamping the police department’s disciplinary process.

items.title: “On the 57th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“On the 57th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech in front of the Lincoln Memorial, hundreds of people filtered in and out of the Greek Theater at Civic Center Park on Friday to listen to speeches about the changes they want to see in local and national institutions that disproportionately harm people of color.”

Denverite

The scheduled protests at Civic Center are scheduled to end at 8 p.m.

denverite.com

Day-long protests and marches continue the conversation about racism’s role in law enforcement

The scheduled protests at Civic Center are scheduled to end at 8 p.m.The scheduled protests at Civic Center are scheduled to end at 8 p.m.

items.title: “The 23-year-old McClain’s death one year ago and the...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The 23-year-old McClain’s death one year ago and the subsequent racial justice protests from earlier this summer have prompted a series of investigations into the Aurora Police Department, including one from Attorney General Phil Weiser.”

Colorado Politics

Aurora intends to hire a new employee to oversee its police department’s policies and procedures, following a series of investigations arising from the August 2019 death of Elijah McClain.

coloradopolitics.com

Aurora to hire police-focused auditor

Aurora intends to hire a new employee to oversee its police department’s policies and procedures, following a series of investigations arising from the August 2019 death of Elijah McClain.Aurora intends to hire a new employee to oversee its police department’s policies and procedures, following a series of investigations arising from the August 2019 death of Elijah McClain.

items.title: “We have extremely clean elections, our elections work really...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“We have extremely clean elections, our elections work really well,” Griswold said. “One of the reasons that we’re considered one of the secure states to cast a ballot is because of mail ballots, because they are a lot safer from cyber attack. You can’t hack a piece of paper.”

The Colorado Sun

Colorado Secretary of State Jena Griswold and county clerks from both parties are defending the state's mail voting system as Donald Trump issues false claims.

coloradosun.com

As Donald Trump pushes disinformation, Colorado election officials reassure public on voting

items.title: This past session we passed 16 bills that took steps forward...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

This past session we passed 16 bills that took steps forward criminal justice reform, workers protections, civil rights, healthcare, and much, more. Now that this whirlwind of a session if over, Rep. Herod is finally taking some time off. This was not an easy thing for her to do. Let’s welcome her back with a surprise! Help us hit our fundraising goal of 100 new donors by September 1st. Click here (https://rb.gy/uaqvfc) to donate $250, $100, $50, or $25 today!

We will be phone banking and lit dropping until Election Day! Sign up here (https://rb.gy/lha6fk) to volunteer.

- Sophie Hackett, Outreach Director

items.title: "As college students nationwide begin a fall semester like...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

"As college students nationwide begin a fall semester like no other, it is tempting to label this an historic moment. This is much more than a moment in time, however. It is not merely a pause before we return to business as usual. It is a movement."

The Denver Post

The challenges we face now herald a movement toward complete transformation and higher education institutions must lead the way.

denverpost.com

CU President Mark Kennedy: Campus changes we’re seeing reflect fundamental shift in higher education

The challenges we face now herald a movement toward complete transformation and higher education institutions must lead the way.The challenges we face now herald a movement toward complete transformation and higher education institutions must lead the way.

items.title: “More commonly, though, people are simply walking and rolling...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“More commonly, though, people are simply walking and rolling down the city’s “shared” streets with fewer threats from drivers of cars and trucks, who are supposed to steer clear of the corridors unless those streets are their final destination. The Department of Transportation and Infrastructure opened select streets to people and (mostly) closed them to cars this spring so Denverites could spread out at a time when close quarters might mean catching the bug. “

Denverite

Petitioners are asking the mayor and his transportation department to make them permanent.

denverite.com

Shared streets and car-free parks will remain at least through the fall

Petitioners are asking the mayor and his transportation department to make them permanent.Petitioners are asking the mayor and his transportation department to make them permanent.

items.title: “They shot my son seven times,” said Jacob Blake Sr., his...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

“They shot my son seven times,” said Jacob Blake Sr., his father, at a news briefing on Tuesday afternoon, growing emotional as he spoke. “Seven times. Like he didn’t matter. But my son matters. He’s a human being, and he matters.”

Washington Post

Shooting in Kenosha, Wis., drove new round of protests across the U.S.

washingtonpost.com

‘My son matters’: Jacob Blake’s family calls for officer’s arrest, peaceful protest

Shooting in Kenosha, Wis., drove new round of protests across the U.S.Shooting in Kenosha, Wis., drove new round of protests across the U.S.

items.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
items.content_html:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.”
